translated: The Collection of Long Sayings
The Discourse on Āḷavaka
Thus have I heard:

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā āḷaviyaṁ viharati āḷavakassa yakkhassa bhavane.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā āḷaviyam viharati āḷavakassa yakkhassa bhavane
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Āḷavī, in the dwelling of the spirit Āḷavaka.

original: Atha kho āḷavako yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho āḷavakaḥ yakkhaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then the spirit Āḷavaka went up to the Buddha and said to him:
“Get out, ascetic.”
“Yes, friend,” said the Buddha and he got out.
“Come in, ascetic.”
“Yes, friend,” said the Buddha and he went in.
A second time …

original: tatiyampi kho āḷavako yakkho bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: tatiyam pi kho āḷavakaḥ yakkhaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: A third time the spirit Āḷavaka said to the Buddha:
“Get out, ascetic.”
“Yes, friend,” said the Buddha and he got out.
“Come in, ascetic.”
“Yes, friend,” said the Buddha and he went in.

original: Catutthampi kho āḷavako yakkho bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: catuttham pi kho āḷavakaḥ yakkhaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: A fourth time the spirit Āḷavaka said to the Buddha:
“Get out, ascetic.”

analyzed: na khvā aham te āvuso nikkhamissāmi
translated: “I won’t get out, friend.

analyzed: yam te karaṇīya tam karohi iti
translated: Do what you have to do.”
“I’ll ask you a question, ascetic.

original: Sace me na byākarissasi, cittaṁ vā te khipissāmi, hadayaṁ vā te phālessāmi, pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipissāmī”ti.
analyzed: sace me na byākarissasi cittam vā te khipissāmi hadayam vā te phālessāmi pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipissāmi iti
translated: If you don’t answer me, I’ll either knock you down and kick you, or I’ll tear open your heart, or I’ll grab you by the feet and throw you to the other side of the Ganges.”

original: “Na khvāhaṁ taṁ, āvuso, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā🔽pajāya sadevamanussāya yo me cittaṁ vā khipeyya hadayaṁ vā phāleyya pādesu vā gahetvā
analyzed: na khvā aham te āvuso passāmi sa devake loke sa mārake sa brahmake sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇiyā  pajāya sa deva manussāya yaḥ me cittam vā khipeyya hadayam vā phāleyya pādesu vā gahetvā
translated: “I don’t see anyone in the cosmos with its gods, lords of death, and contemplatives and brahmans,
in this world with its humans and gods, who could knock me down and kick me, or who could tear open my heart, or who could grab me by the feet and throw me to the other side of the Ganges.

original: Api ca tvaṁ, āvuso, puccha yadākaṅkhasī”ti.
analyzed: api ca tvai āvuso puccha yat ākaṅkhasi iti
translated: But still, friend, ask me whatever you want.”

original: Atha kho āḷavako yakkho bhagavantaṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
analyzed: atha kho āḷavakaḥ yakkhaḥ bhagavantam gāthāya ajjhabhāsi
translated: Then the spirit Āḷavaka addressed the Blessed One with a verse:
“What is the best of a person’s possessions?

original: Kiṁ su suciṇṇaṁ sukhamāvahāti;🔽Kiṁ su have sādutaraṁ rasānaṁ,
analyzed: kim su su ciṇṇam sukham āvahāti  kim su have sādutaram rasāna
translated: What, when well-practiced, brings happiness?🔽What is the best of tastes?
How does one live the best life?”

analyzed: saddhi idha vittam purisassa seṭṭha  dhammaḥ su ciṇṇaḥ sukham āvahāti
translated: “Faith is the best of a person’s possessions.🔽Dhamma, when well-practiced, brings happiness.
Truth is the best of tastes.
One who lives by wisdom is said to live the best life.”

original: “Kathaṁ su tarati oghaṁ,🔽kathaṁ su tarati aṇṇavaṁ;
analyzed: katham su tarati ogha  katham su tarati anṇava
translated: “How does one cross the flood?🔽How does one cross the abyss?
How does one overcome suffering?
How does one become purified?”
“With faith one crosses the flood,
with diligence the abyss.
With energy one overcomes suffering,

original: paññāya parisujjhati”.🔽“Kathaṁ su labhate paññaṁ,🔽kathaṁ su vindate dhanaṁ;
analyzed: paññāya parisujjhati  katham su labhate pañña  katham su vindate dhana
translated: with wisdom one becomes purified.”🔽“How does one gain wisdom?🔽How does one find wealth?
How does one gain a good reputation?
How does one make friends?
From this world to the next,
how does one not grieve after death?”
“One who has faith in the Worthy Ones,
in the Dhamma leading to Nibbāna,
listening attentively gains wisdom,
diligent and discerning.
One who does what is fitting, who is strong,
who is energetic finds wealth.
Through truth one gains a good reputation,
through giving one makes friends.
For one who has these four things,
a faithful householder,
truth, Dhamma, patience, and generosity,

original: sa ve pecca na socati.🔽Iṅgha aññepi pucchassu,🔽puthū samaṇabrāhmaṇe;
analyzed: sa ve pet ca na socati  iṅgha aññe pi pucchassu  puthū samaṇa brāhmaṇe
translated: he does not grieve after death.🔽Go and ask other ascetics and brahmins,

analyzed: yadi sat cā damā ca āgā
translated: if they have truth, self-control, and generosity,
There is no one more patient than he.”
“How should I ask
The many monastics and brahmins,
Since I now understand
What is beneficial for the next life.
The Buddha has indeed come
To stay in Āḷavī for my benefit,
Since I now understand

analyzed: yattha dinnam mahapphala  saḥ aham vicarissāmi
translated: Where a gift is very fruitful.🔽I will wander
From village to village, from town to town,
Paying homage to the Buddha,
And to the true Dhamma’s good teaching.”
The Discourse on Āḷavī is the tenth.
